text.__SUMMARY__: Amblyodipsas rodhaini, commonly known as Rodhain's purple-glossed snake, is a species of venomous rear-fanged snake in the family Lamprophiidae. The species is endemic to the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
text.Etymology: Both the specific name, rodhaini, and the common name, Rodhain's purple-glossed snake, are in honor of Belgian physician and zoologist Jérome Alphonse Hubert Rodhain (1876–1956).
text.Further reading:
de Witte GF (1930). "Un serpent do Congo Belge (Rhinocalamus rhodaini sp. n.)". Rev. Zool. Bot. Afr. 19 (1): 1-3.
Branch, Bill (2005). A Photographic Guide to Snakes, Other Reptiles and Amphibians of East Africa. Cape Town: Struik. p. 67.
